183619277.review:
The Long Dark is an exceptionally good and utterly addicting survival experience that captivates from the very start. In my opinion, it stands out as one of the most immersive and well-crafted survival games ever created.

The survival mechanics are incredibly realistic, with every element feeling meticulously designed. From managing hunger, thirst, and warmth to navigating the harsh wilderness and unpredictable weather, the game offers a challenging yet deeply rewarding experience. In my opinion, I loved the feature when a blizzard unexpectedly happens throughout the day without any type of warning. It’s clear that the developers poured immense thought and care into every aspect of survival, ensuring an authentic and engaging adventure.

The visuals are stunning in their minimalist style, perfectly capturing the beauty and danger of the Canadian wilderness. The sound design further enhances the immersion, with the haunting winds and cracking ice keeping you constantly on edge.

Each decision matters, and the tension of balancing limited resources and surviving another day keeps you hooked. Whether you’re scavenging for supplies, crafting tools, or simply trying to find shelter from an approaching blizzard, the game pulls you into its world like few others can.

The only problem I have with this game is the game's episodes. Currently, the story isn't finished. I have owned this game since 2020 and it still not finished. This game was released on 2014. That's the only downside of this game. I hope this upcoming 2025, it would be finished.

For anyone who loves survival games or simply wants a gripping and unforgettable gaming experience, The Long Dark is a must-play. I give it a solid 10/10 and highly recommend it to anyone looking for a true test of skill and resilience. This game is not just an adventure. It’s a journey of survival and self-discovery.

183613108.review:
This review is gonna mainly touch on the game as a whole and the story mode specifically. It's a bit strange because this really feels like two different games - Wintermute (which is the story mode) and Survival (which is in the base game but greatly expanded by the DLC Tales from the Far Territory).

Wintermute has been in development for about 10~ years now, and is about to come to a close with the final episode dropping soon. If you'd like to read my review for Survival mode specifically, please take a look at my review of the DLC Tales from the Far Territory.

[h1] The Quiet Apocalypse [/h1]

What Hinterland Studios has done here is create a beautiful world to explore and get lost in. At first glance, it might seem boring to you - it moves slowly, you're mainly trying to just get from one place to another to scrounge enough supplies to keep surviving and stave off the cold.

In that moment to moment gameplay though, it's peaceful. It may feel like death is constantly nipping at your heels, but you can find a good groove to keep yourself moving forward and enjoying the world.

The world itself is fascinating, with a light Sci-Fi theme and a near future apocalypse that wiped out all electronic devices. Although the world itself is fascinating and presents grand mysteries, the main story mode so far has focused on the small scale story following only a couple of characters. (I'm only on episode 3 so far, so we'll see how it goes.)

The story is decent, though the writing and voice acting can feel a bit forced and heavy handed, at times. That being said, it continues to be interesting enough to carry me forward, and it honestly feels like it's a good introduction to the survival systems that you will more thoroughly utilize in survival mode. 

Wintermute has been released episodically, so here's my overall vibe check for each episode.

[b]Episode 1:[/b] Really nice introduction to the world and the characters. Great way to get a vibe for the atmosphere.
[b]Episode 2:[/b] This was a cool one. More survival systems and a cool narrative threat.
[b]Episode 3:[/b] Hope you like fetch quests and walking slower than usual! Cool narrative core, quite a bit slower than the other episodes so far. Not as wild about this one.
[b]Episode 4:[/b] [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sAXZbfLzJUg]WOOOO yeah baby! That's what I've been waiting for, that's what it's all about!![/url] (Also I don't think the ESRB got to this episode...)
[b]Episode 5:[/b] TBD

It's important to note that I'm coming in towards the "end" of this development cycle. The story mode is almost finished. To the people who have been waiting for the story mode to finish or the survival mode to get properly fleshed out for 10 years, I could understand some frustration, and I [i]do see[/i] that frustration online. However, the vast majority even among longtime fans is support and admiration for the game. The developers take care of their own people, and they work with the fans. That's something that's becoming rarer and rarer these days.

Though it does beg the question, should you jump straight into The Long Dark 2 when it comes out? I know I will. But you'll have to be patient. That may well be the beginning of another incredibly long development cycle to build on to the game, but hopefully at the beginning they will apply enough of the lessons learned with this game to create the foundation of something truly incredible.

But I digress - The Long Dark 2 is the future of the IP and the studio. [i]This[/i] game is nearly complete, though they have said they will continue to update and tweak it. If the vibe and atmosphere sounds interesting or appealing to you, what is available is an incredible game and package, and it's been more than worth it to me.
